comment.author: 13073434@N03

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/13073434@N03] Wherever else the camera's pointing, it's not east. That would put the sun in the north west, which could only happen on a winter's evening but the photo is at noon in summer.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: If you look on the satellite view of the field behind this, there's a lot of cutting remnants(binged.it/ZxbLvJ). Could this be the roundy hill in the background? maps.google.ie/?ll=54.827689,-6.022997&spn=0.009221,0.... Depending on the time of day we could be looking north west.

comment.author: 8468254@N02

comment.author: 13073434@N03

I know the roads as I'm on them frequently living where I do.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I'll happily be proved wrong but the land is too flat to be anywhere other than the Garry Bog. I'm working off Gerry's photo. www.flickr.com/photos/13073434@N03/8541225957/in/photostream

comment.author: 13073434@N03

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/13073434@N03] A histogram equalisation is when you change the value distribution of the grey-scale palette so that each value is represented the same number of times. It highlights objects that are at the extremes of the distribution. In the link I posted, you can see that a number of new hills have magically appeared in the background.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: I reckon this is the pointy hill in the background, but it's taken from a couple of miles further back: maps.google.com/maps?q=Old+Frosses+Road,+Ballymena,+Unite... Somewhere around the meeting house on the springmount road or on the dowgry road.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Getting closer. This one has both the background hills and Slemish in it: maps.google.com/maps?q=Old+Frosses+Road,+Ballymena,+Unite...

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: Think this be it: Buildings on near hill. Far away hills coincide. Drumack (6"OSI) on Aghill Road. Drumack Bog is 9miles NW of Ballymena and approximately 18miles WNW of Slemish Street View OS 6" red + close to where I reckon pictures were take from. maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,700245,912286,4,3

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: This is the view as per Gerry Ward's "another one" with Slemish seen ever so faintly on the right. Street View The building behind the bungalow has only one external chimney stack. The white building in the NLI photo has also one chimney stack but i cannot make out whether it is external or not. Too bright. maps.google.com/maps?q=Aghill+Road,+Ballymena,+United+Kin...

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] I think you're marginally too far north but I reckon you've got the right bit of bog and more or less the right view. Well done. 

I should draw diagrams before I get too certain about the direction from the sun. If the sun is more or less due west, the shadows are fine for looking north-east.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Any further south the drumlin would have been in shot. Notice the gable of the white building creeping into top left of Gerry's "another one" photo!!!   With thanks to your historygram equalisation machinery and you were right about the photo being taken late afternoon early evening...... I need  to change the oil on my mouse after all that Google map driving!!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] You're welcome. 1901 census returns show there were 278 people "living" on that 1256 acre, top of a mountain, townland of Drumack. A lot list their occupations as 'linen weavers'. The white building with the high windows may have therefore been a weaving shed and had looms in. 1901 Census

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: I went to the bog and here are the photos: www.flickr.com/photos/13073434@N03/sets/72157632969564711/ There is no sign of any buildings as shown on the photo above. Just upland bog and no hill behind as shown in the photo.

comment.author: 8468254@N02

comment.author: 13073434@N03

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/13073434@N03] Robin, you went so far above and beyond the call of duty on this one. I can only imagine how cold it must have been - feared there'd be reports of frostbite!

Sorry that you couldn't find the spot, but I really like the first two photos in the set especially - very moody and windswept...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/13073434@N03] You've got the direction alright. It just looked so convincing in TinOfBeans's link yesterday.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/13073434@N03] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] The Camera in the original could have been on top of a "rick" of turf, and ground level could be significantly lower than 130 years ago. This was turf cutting on an industrial scale!

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] True. You can still see the scars on the aerial photos.

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I assume you mean the bog on the Drumack Road. That bog is still being worked. You can see the full fertilizer bags in rows in the aerial shot. What direction is the camera pointing in the photo Carol posted? Have you changed the time of day from midday to late evening? They'd be eaten alive by the midges in the evening. We would have had a liberal covering of old perfume to keep them off us. I looked at the scene to the west of the Craigs Road and nearly fell for it due to the two hills being nearly like the hills in the distance in this photo. See what you think. maps.google.com/maps?q=Drumack+Road,+Rasharkin,+United+Ki...

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/13073434@N03] I drew a few diagrams and it still looks like around midday (there's no long shadows anywhere) but the sun could be from the west rather than south if it's early afternoon, so we could be looking east to north-east. Equally, though, the sun could be east or south meaning the photo linked by Gerry with slemish in it was taken looking the opposite direction to the one above (or in a completely different place). I was hoping the additional mountains I put in with my techno-wizardry would let you recognise the place.

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Carol says she's 99.9% convinced that they were taken at the same place and on the same day. Gerry's 'another one' shows the same family dressed in the same clothes as this one here. It has to be facing east for Slemish to be where it is in that particular photo. Aren't the shadows quite short? I hoped that the additional detail would have helped me to place it but it hasn't been possible yet. What are your thoughts about the mountains in the Streetview I posted? I haven't been able to get back to the area since Monday for the engine died on the way home and it's still waiting to be sorted :(

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The pointy hill in the middle with the smaller peak to its right might be the one on the right in the processed image I posted, but I wouldn't be at all sure. If it is, where's the middle one form the processed pic? Alternatively, is it the middle one from the processed pic but from further north or south?

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: In this view from west of Glarryford, Slemish looks quite narrow compared to the "The Garry Bog" photo. maps.google.com/maps?q=Aghill+Road,+Ballymena,+United+Kin.... Is it too far away or the is it wrong angle?

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I saved your processed photo and managed to position it on top of the Streetview so the pointy hill in the middle lined up with the pointy hill in the Streetview at the Craigs Road. It looked very plausible but I  need to, at least, find wallsteads The Streetview west of Glarryford doesn't make Slemish look that much narrower than my photo taken from the bog. I is just a wee bit further north than where I was standing in the bog. I had the benefit of very clear air as you can see when you compare mine with the Streetview. My photo is closer the Gerry's photo in that respect.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Do you think we're seeing mirroring again? This view from the Craigs road seems to match the background mountains pretty exactly if they were reversed. maps.google.com/maps?q=Drumack+Road,+Rasharkin,+United+Ki... (It's not the right place - I just chose it because it gave a good view of the background from what we think is the right general direction). Is there anything in the picture to hint at left or right?

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The only thing I can see is that if it's reversed, the man in the foreground would be left-handed. Hardly conclusive either way.

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I have come to the conclusion that the camera in this photo is pointing north east and east in Gerry's photo. Evidence: The man's wife and son are too slow in footing the turf and he has no more room to fire anymore out of the hole so he gets up and starts to foot the turf along with them. The wee lad stays in the hole but both lads are so taken with the man and his camera that they are not as productive as they should be. The side of the hole facing the camera is the same in both photos with the same marks on it from the slan(e). I didn't notice before but is the corner of the shed with the outside toilet that is in the top right of this photo in the top left of Gerry's? That means I have been looking the wrong direction all the time :(

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/13073434@N03] Is that because I told you the wrong direction?

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I doubt it. Have a look at this! www.flickr.com/photos/13073434@N03/8557257664/in/photostream

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/13073434@N03] That's it, alright, so east to north-east, as per Beans's suggestion. It means it's definitely not mirrored either, as there's no hills like that south of Slemish.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: What's the weird grid, btw. Did you photograph this instead of screengrabbing it?

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I photographed it for I don't know how to do a screen grab. I think we're getting somewhere.

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I've managed to do a screenshot and replaced the one in my photostream. It has to be an improvement.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/13073434@N03] Thanks for your sterling work on this one, Robin, lot least for risking frost bite! I have to admit, I'm totally lost at this stage. If only Robert French, if it was he who took this photograph, had added compass points to his notes on it!

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] We're an awful lot closer than we were. The jointer is the key. We'll get it. It may take a bit of time but we don't give up. Remember Adrigole?

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/13073434@N03] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Exactly. We got lucky with Linen Bleach Green, but we'll get this one eventually.

comment._content: Could it be as far north as the Glenbuck road? There's a pretty good match with the horizon if you could get the intervening scenery right.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content:
Has to be............
Both pictures taken from same location except camera moved to edge of bank for 2nd (another one)
The road going off at an angle from left to right in above picture is the Drumack rd. The white building in both photos was situated where the present farmhouse is---near the Drumack rd/Aghill Rd junction.
The gap in the ditch above is probable the same gap seen on GMaps today....????

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I was when creating this: www.flickr.com/photos/13073434@N03/8559509698/in/photostr... That road runs on quite a length and there's what looks like a church or hall on the left of the road. I have a 1" map of the area opened. It's around 50 years old. My car is still off the road and I'm heading out now but will be back on the case as soon as I return.

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I think it's too far north. I'm off to Portrush now so I'll sit on the right hand side of the train and see if I can spot anything.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
The Turf Bog Limerick When you're lost in an Irish turf bog, And you can't see the way through the fog ... A prayer to Saint Patrick ? Or help psychiatric ? Or maybe the hair of the dog ?
[Posted on St Patrick's Day, 17/3/2013]

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Your Best one yet. Happy St Patricks day to you. 

 I have just seen a picture of ??

 [http://www.flickr.com/photos/degi-ichi/4440692676/]

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] A good one there! We'll need all the help we can get on this one. I'm off to Ballymena tomorrow armed with maps, photos and compass once the snow, that has been forecast for tonight, clears. Then again it might be Wednesday before I manage. It just might be nearer Ballymena than we think.......

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/13073434@N03] So did you manage to get out or was there too much weather?

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] The weather is grim up here. We have snow but I'm hoping to get out today. Everything is in the car ready to go. I've some work to do before I get out. There's a museum in Ballymena and I will go there first before doing more scouting around. It opens at 10.00am. We'll get it. There has to be some of those buildings still around for there are too many for them all to have vanished. There's a building that looks as if it is on the left of the road running past the bog. It has two pitched slate roofs in a style similar to Arklow Presbyterian Church. It should still be there. Update: Been up in the district and still no joy. System of elimination.

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I went to the tourist office in Ballymena and the lady with whom I spoke took two of my photos and will be speaking with a neighbour (80+) tonight and will email me on Friday. Meanwhile the search goes on.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/13073434@N03] Phew! You made it back in one piece. I've been watching out for alerts on UTV in case you were found frozen in the middle of the bog.

Huzzah for the lady in Ballymena tourist office and her neighbour. And thank you for all of your efforts in quest of this location!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] If only I could find it! The forecast is not good for Thursday and Friday so I will be searching Google between other things.

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/13073434@N03] They have a tourist office in Ballymena?

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward] It's like a lost property office. If anyone finds a tourist lying about, they bring it there so its owners can reclaim it.

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward] I mentioned that it was very quiet but was told it was busier earlier on. Lovely place. I've been at a concert there. It's part of the Braid Arts Centre. A new building attached to the town hall.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: Same family used on a postcard! [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03/8991125109/]

comment.author: 48236157@N02
comment._content: Great photo!
